According to news originating from Chicago, Illinois, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated,“ Materials that show superior light-emitting and catalytic properties are in high demand among the scientific...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Nanotech Daily
\-- Current study results on Nanotechnology - Nanoparticles have been
published. According to news originating from Chicago, Illinois, by NewsRx
correspondents, research stated, "Materials that show superior light-emitting
and catalytic properties are in high demand among the scientific community
owing to their applications in the areas of optoelectronics and
(opto)electrocatalysis. In this work, we have synthesized sub-10-nm Pr2Sn2O7
(PSO) and Pr2Sn2O7:Bi3+ (PSOB) nanoparticles (NPs) and investigated their
optical and electrochemical properties."

Funders for this research include IIT startup funds, United States-India
Education Foundation (USIEF, India), Institute of International Education
(IIE, USA).

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from IIT, "On
ultraviolet irradiation, PSO NPs display blue emission because of the presence
of oxygen vacancies. Interestingly, PSOB NPs have higher blue emission
intensity than undoped PSO NPs owing to the increase in oxygen vacancy defect
density induced by Bi3+ doping. Moreover, PSOB NPs display higher efficiency
in terms of current density than PSO NPs as a catalyst toward the oxygen
evolution reaction (OER). The kinetic OER models of PSO and PSOB NPs are quite
different as displayed by their different Tafel slopes. Interestingly and as
another advantage, the PSOB sample is more conducting with low impedance value
than the PSO counterpart."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "With all these
advantages due to high oxygen vacancies induced by Bi3+ doping, PSOB NPs have
a great potential to be used as blue phosphors, charge storage devices, and
capacitors."

For more information on this research see: Defect-induced Optical and
Electrochemical Properties of Pr2sn2o7 Nanoparticles Enhanced By Bi3+ Doping.
_Journal of Materials Research_ , 2020;35(9):1214-1224. _Journal of Materials
Research_ can be contacted at: Cambridge Univ Press, 32 Avenue Of The
Americas, New York, NY 10013-2473, USA. (Cambridge University Press \-
[www.cambridge.org](http://www.cambridge.org); Journal of Materials Research
\- <http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayJournal?jid=JMR>)

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained
from Y.B. Mao, IIT, Dept. of Chemistry, Chicago, IL 60616, United States.
Additional authors for this research include A. Abraham, S. Mohan, H. Abdou
and S.K. Gupta.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1557/jmr.2020.48>. This DOI is a link to an online
electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your
direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Researchers from IIT Detail Findings in Nanoparticles (Defect-induced Optical and Electrochemical Properties of Pr2sn2o7 Nanoparticles Enhanced By Bi3+ Doping): Nanotechnology - Nanoparticles
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at Nanotech Daily -- Current study results on Nanotechnology - Nanoparticles have been published. According to news originating from Chicago, Illinois, by NewsRx correspondents, research stated, “Materials that show superior light-emitting and catalytic properties are in high demand among the scientific community owing to their applications in the areas of optoelectronics and (opto)electrocatalysis. In this work, we have synthesized sub-10-nm Pr2Sn2O7 (PSO) and Pr2Sn2O7:Bi3+ (PSOB) nanoparticles (NPs) and investigated their optical and electrochemical properties.”

Funders for this research include IIT startup funds, United States-India Education Foundation (USIEF, India), Institute of International Education (IIE, USA).

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from IIT, “On ultraviolet irradiation, PSO NPs display blue emission because of the presence of oxygen vacancies. Interestingly, PSOB NPs have higher blue emission intensity than undoped PSO NPs owing to the increase in oxygen vacancy defect density induced by Bi3+ doping. Moreover, PSOB NPs display higher efficiency in terms of current density than PSO NPs as a catalyst toward the oxygen evolution reaction (OER). The kinetic OER models of PSO and PSOB NPs are quite different as displayed by their different Tafel slopes. Interestingly and as another advantage, the PSOB sample is more conducting with low impedance value than the PSO counterpart.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “With all these advantages due to high oxygen vacancies induced by Bi3+ doping, PSOB NPs have a great potential to be used as blue phosphors, charge storage devices, and capacitors.”

For more information on this research see: Defect-induced Optical and Electrochemical Properties of Pr2sn2o7 Nanoparticles Enhanced By Bi3+ Doping. Journal of Materials Research, 2020;35(9):1214-1224. Journal of Materials Research can be contacted at: Cambridge Univ Press, 32 Avenue Of The Americas, New York, NY 10013-2473, USA. (Cambridge University Press - www.cambridge.org; Journal of Materials Research - http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayJournal?jid=JMR)

The news correspondents report that additional information may be obtained from Y.B. Mao, IIT, Dept. of Chemistry, Chicago, IL 60616, United States. Additional authors for this research include A. Abraham, S. Mohan, H. Abdou and S.K. Gupta.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1557/jmr.2020.48. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
